item.title: Did the Louvre just disappear?
item.ExtractedText: 1 of 12 12 photos: JR 'hides' the Louvre JR au Louvre – Titled "JR au Louvre," the artist is covering the museum's glass pyramid -- designed by Chinese-American architect I.M. Pei -- in one of his signature black and white photographs. Hide Caption 2 of 12 12 photos: JR 'hides' the Louvre JR au Louvre – The installation makes it appear as if the glass pyramid has disappeared, drawing attention to the original museum that lies behind. Hide Caption 3 of 12 12 photos: JR 'hides' the Louvre Women Are Heroes – JR's work has been exhibited around the world. His "Women Are Heroes" project photographed women and pasted the images in visible places within their communities, and further afield. Hide Caption 4 of 12 12 photos: JR 'hides' the Louvre Women Are Heroes – The project ran from 2008 to 2014, when 2,600 strips of paper featuring the faces of women from around the world were pasted onto a container ship in La Havre, France, before it set sail for Malaysia. Hide Caption 5 of 12 12 photos: JR 'hides' the Louvre Elmar – The New York Times commissioned this piece, called "Elmar", for the launch of their Walking New York issue in 2015. Hide Caption 6 of 12 12 photos: JR 'hides' the Louvre Face to Face – JR and his friend Marco went to the Middle East in 2005 and captured a series of photographs of Palestinian and Israeli people they met on their travels. In 2007, JR paired these photos face to face and plastered the images on walls in cities across Israel and Palestine. This photo is of Separation Wall, on the Palestinian side in Bethlehem. Hide Caption 7 of 12 12 photos: JR 'hides' the Louvre Au Pantheon! – JR showcased 2,500 portraits from around the world to help celebrate the newly refurbished Pantheon in Paris in 2014. Faces lined the floor, walls and exteriors of the secular temple where many famous French people are buried. Hide Caption 8 of 12 12 photos: JR 'hides' the Louvre Portrait of a Generation – JR took this photo of young French-Malian man Ladj Ly's as part of his "Portrait of a Generation" project. At first glance the man looks as though he's pointing a gun, but it is in fact a camera -- the photo challenges the ideas of clichés in visual culture. Hide Caption 9 of 12 12 photos: JR 'hides' the Louvre Unframed – The "Unframed - Ellis Island" project was a series of installations built within abandoned buildings on Ellis Island. Located next to the Statue of Liberty in New York, the island acted as an entry point into America for millions of immigrants from 1892 to 1954. Hide Caption 10 of 12 12 photos: JR 'hides' the Louvre New York City Ballet – JR created two large works for New York City Ballet's Art Series program, that invites contemporary artists into the Lincoln Center. This image is a massive trompe l'oeil rendering of an eye created with life-size photos of NYCB dancers on the floor of the Promenade. Hide Caption 11 of 12 12 photos: JR 'hides' the Louvre Expo 2 Rue – Expo 2 Rue is one of JR's earlier projects. After finding a camera in the Paris Metro, the artist began to document his own graffiti as well as the work of other artists. At 17 he began pasting photocopies of these photographs onto outdoor walls, turning the city's streets into open galleries for everyone to see. Hide Caption
